newsitem.title: USA: Apple's Claris Q1 revenue rises 12 percent.
newsitem.headline: Apple's Claris Q1 revenue rises 12 percent.

text.p: Claris Corp, the software unit of Apple Computer Inc, said revenue in its fiscal first quarter rose 12 percent on strong Japanese sales and on sales of Windows products.
The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said revenue for the quarter ended December 27 rose to $67 million from $59.7 million in the same quarter a year ago.
The sales increase shows there is strong demand for Macintosh software, even though Apple had a tough time selling computers to consumers in the same quarter, said Guerrino De Luca, Claris president.
"We're pretty happy about this," De Luca said. "Each of the elements of the business grew."

Claris, which operates as a separate business, writes business software, such as word processors and databases, for Macintosh computers. It also distributes and sells upgrades of the Macintosh operating system. And it sells versions of its applications for personal computers running Microsoft Corp's Windows operating system.
De Luca said the Windows version of its FileMaker Pro database sold well in the quarter.
The company also had strong growth from Japan, where it recently released Japanese versions of key products.
Claris, owned completely by Apple, does not disclose profits. De Luca declined to say whether the company had a profit in the quarter.
In the December quarter, Apple reported an unexpected loss of $120 million because of weak sales of consumer-oriented Performa Macintosh computers.
Analysts have said further losses from Apple could discourage software companies from writing programs for the Macintosh, leading more customers to avoid buying Macs.
